keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle, a convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after a family alerted authorities that he had planned to 'shoot it up' on a live social media stream.
Cagle was found in possession of an AR-15 assault rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in a Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the airport terminal.
The arrest was made possible through a tip from his family, who noticed concerning social media posts indicating a violent intent.

Cagle has been charged with making terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, possession of a firearm during the commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a felon.
Police and federal officials are investigating how Cagle obtained the firearm, which authorities say he was not legally permitted to possess.
The incident is seen as a success in preventing mass violence, with officials praising the family's vigilance and the effectiveness of community-based early warning systems.

A close friend of Cagle, Nick Roberts, noted that Cagle had been struggling with mental health issues and had previously disclosed schizophrenia, suggesting a possible link between mental illness and violent behavior.
The case raises broader public concerns about firearm access, social media as a platform for threats, and the role of mental health in violent acts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A 49-year-old convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, Billy Joe Cagle, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after his family alerted authorities that he had planned to 'shoot it up' during a live social media livestream. Police found an AR-15 assault rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the terminal. Cagle, who had previously disclosed mental health struggles including schizophrenia, was charged with making terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, and illegal firearm possession. The incident was averted due to early detection by family members, and officials praised the vigilance of the community and effective law enforcement coordination. Federal authorities are investigating how he obtained the weapon, which he was not legally allowed to possess. The case highlights risks posed by social media threats, mental health challenges, and the importance of community-based early warning systems.
